abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, although the
            institutional development impact is negligible. Lessons are
            as follows. Policy-based lending has been an effective
            mechanism of support in Mali, but structural adjustment
            credits may not be the best mechanism for supporting public
            enterprise divestitures. Privatization is a complex process,
            particularly given the fragility of Mali's economy and
            high vulnerability to exogenous shocks, thereby forcing the
            Bank to either amend its conditionality, or penalize the
            government for good performance under difficult
            circumstances. The Bank supported a process that would not
            only be anti-competitive in outcome, but which was also
            likely to be markedly less attractive to potential
            investors; similarly, the Bank's acquiescence in the
            government's decision not to use an investment advisor,
            in a country fraught with capacity weaknesses, further
            weakened the likelihood of privatization success. This also
            suggests the need to ensure up-front that key implementing
            institutions have sufficient resources, since the shortfall
            of other donor funding had the potential to substantially
            undermine credit implementation. Instead, future operations
            should explicitly ensure that funding, technical assistance,
            etc. be reliably available; alternatively, provision of such
            funding should be included in the Bank's operation to
            make certain that it is forthcoming. Other lessons outline
            the need for maintaining a tight focus on a limited number
            of reforms; for an effective partnership with donors; and,
            for an effective partnership with the International Monetary Fund.
